context:
Using the Admin Phone
1
Using the Admin Phone
The Bogen Model NQ-T1100 by Yealink is designed to serve as the 
Administrative Display Phone, or Admin Phone, for Nyquist E7000 
Series systems. This phone combines a traditional telephone keypad 
with a color touch screen to provide rapid, efficient, and reliable con-
trol over many Nyquist E7000 features, such as launching Emergency-
All-Call pages and managing school bell schedules. 
This manual guides you through the use of the Admin Phone with the 
Nyquist system.
1
Hardware Components and Features
The main components of the Admin Phone are the 7-inch 800 x 480 
pixel 24-bit color touch screen display and the keypad. In addition to 
the traditional 12 push-button dial pad, the Admin Phone features 7 
feature keys, 6 navigational keys, and volume control keys.

The feature keys are described in the following table:

qas.question: What is the primary function of the Bogen Model NQ-T1100 by Yealink?

answers.text: The primary function of the Bogen Model NQ-T1100 by Yealink is to serve as the Administrative Display Phone (Admin Phone) for Nyquist E7000 Series systems. It provides efficient control over features such as Emergency-All-Call pages and managing school bell schedules through its traditional keypad and color touch screen interface.

qas.question: What are the key features of the Admin Phone's display?

answers.text: The Admin Phone features a 7-inch color touch screen that displays information about calls, messages, and status, along with the current bell schedule if one exists. The interface allows for quick access to launch pages, change schedules, and utilize other Nyquist system features, enhancing user efficiency and convenience.

qas.question: How does the touch screen enhance the user experience with the Nyquist E7000 system?

answers.text: The touch screen enhances the user experience with the Nyquist E7000 system by providing a graphical user interface (GUI) that allows for quick navigation between screens and easy access to features such as launching Emergency-All-Call pages and managing bell schedules. This intuitive interface improves efficiency and control, making it convenient for users to interact with various functions of the system.

qas.question: What functions do the feature keys on the Admin Phone perform?

answers.text: The feature keys on the Admin Phone perform various functions: they toggle headset and mute modes, retrieve voicemail messages, place or resume held calls, redial the last number called, transfer calls to other extensions, and toggle hands-free speakerphone mode. These keys facilitate quick and efficient control over Nyquist E7000 system features.

qas.question: How can users retrieve voice mail messages using the Admin Phone?

answers.text: Users can retrieve voice mail messages on the Admin Phone by pressing the dedicated voice mail feature key, provided the Nyquist system is set up for this functionality. The touch screen interface will guide them through accessing their messages.

qas.question: What does the current bell schedule display indicate on the idle screen?

answers.text: The current bell schedule display at the top of the idle screen indicates the operational timings for your facility, such as when bells will ring. It provides quick access to schedule information alongside any important system messages or alerts.

qas.question: Which functionalities do the navigation keys provide on the Admin Phone?

answers.text: The navigation keys on the Admin Phone allow users to scroll through menus and options on the touch screen display, facilitating swift access to various features and settings of the Nyquist E7000 system. They aid in navigating through call information, messages, and schedules efficiently.

qas.question: How does the Admin Phone facilitate call management, such as hold and transfer?

answers.text: The Admin Phone facilitates call management by allowing users to place calls on hold or resume held calls using a dedicated feature key. Additionally, it enables users to transfer calls to another extension easily, enhancing overall call handling efficiency within the Nyquist system.

qas.question: What type of information appears beneath the bell schedule on the idle screen?

answers.text: Beneath the bell schedule on the idle screen, system messages such as incoming Emergency Calls, as well as any operational or error messages, are displayed. This area provides important notifications related to the phone's status and functionality.

qas.question: What resolution does the Admin Phone's touch screen offer?

answers.text: The Admin Phone's touch screen offers a resolution of 800 x 480 pixels with 24-bit color. This allows for clear display of information and a user-friendly graphical interface.

context:
Configuring the NQ-T1100 Admin Phone
Refer to the Nyquist System Administrator Manual for instructions on 
adding the phone as a station. You will need the Extension Number, 
Name, and MAC address for the phone.
Next, configure the Admin Phone through the phone’s web user 
interface (UI).
Figure 3, Auto Provision Options
To configure the Admin Phone:
Step 1
Identify the Admin Phone’s Internet Protocol (IP) 
address by doing one of the following:
•
Locate the IP address in your network’s Dynamic 
Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) client table.

Press the Admin Phone’s OK navigation key to dis-
play the IP address.
Step 2
Open your computer’s web browser, enter the Admin 
Phone’s IP address (for example, http://192.168.0.10 or 
192.168.0.10) in the address bar, and then press Enter. 
The computer will display the Admin Phone web UI. 
Step 3
On the logon page, enter the Username (default is 
admin) and Password (default is bogen) and click 
Confirm.
Step 4
Click the Settings tab.
Step 5
Click Auto Provision.
Step 6
Select Off for PNP Active.
Step 7
Select Off for DHCP Active.
Step 8
Click Confirm.
Step 9
Reboot the phone by unplugging the network connec-
tion.
The phone will reboot, automatically download its configuration 
information from the server, and reboot a second time to come 
online.
3
Making Pages
Nyquist allows the following types of intercom pages:
• Multi-Site All-Call
• Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call
• All-Call
• Emergency All-Call
• Station or Zone

qas.question: What information is required to add the NQ-T1100 Admin Phone as a station?

answers.text: To add the NQ-T1100 Admin Phone as a station, you need the Extension Number, Name, and MAC address of the phone. Refer to the Nyquist System Administrator Manual for specific instructions on the process.

qas.question: How can you identify the Admin Phone's IP address?

answers.text: You can identify the Admin Phone's IP address by either locating it in your network's Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) client table or by pressing the Admin Phone's OK navigation key to display the IP address directly on the phone screen.

qas.question: What is the default Username and Password for accessing the Admin Phone's web UI?

answers.text: The default Username for accessing the Admin Phone's web UI is "admin," and the default Password is "bogen."

qas.question: Which settings need to be turned Off during the Auto Provision configuration for the Admin Phone?

answers.text: During the Auto Provision configuration for the Admin Phone, both PNP Active and DHCP Active settings need to be turned Off.

qas.question: What action must be taken to reboot the Admin Phone after configuration changes?

answers.text: To reboot the Admin Phone after configuration changes, unplug the network connection. The phone will then reboot, automatically download its configuration from the server, and reboot a second time to come online.

qas.question: What types of intercom pages does Nyquist support?

answers.text: Nyquist supports the following types of intercom pages: Multi-Site All-Call, Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call, All-Call, Emergency All-Call, and Station or Zone.

qas.question: Where do you navigate to configure the Auto Provision settings on the Admin Phone?

answers.text: To configure the Auto Provision settings on the Admin Phone, navigate to the Settings tab in the web user interface (UI) after logging in. Then, click on Auto Provision to access and modify the necessary settings.

qas.question: How does the Admin Phone determine its configuration information after rebooting?

answers.text: After rebooting, the Admin Phone automatically downloads its configuration information from the server using the settings previously configured in the web UI. This process is initiated due to the specific configurations that were set to disable PNP and DHCP, allowing the phone to rely on a static configuration setup.

context:
7
Even if your Nyquist phone is not set up to make multiple site pages, 
Multi-Site All-Call and Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call buttons 
appear on the phone’s display.
3.1
Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call Paging
A Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page is an emergency page that 
plays simultaneously throughout multiple sites that are configued in 
the facilities list. It has the highest priority of all pages.
To make a hands-free Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page using the 
touch display:
Step 1
Touch the Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call button.
Step 2
Talk into the phone’s microphone.
Step 3
Touch End Call when finished.
To make a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page using the handset:
Step 1
Pick up the handset.
Step 2
When the dial screen appears, touch the +More but-
ton.
Step 3
Touch the Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call button.
Step 4
Talk into the handset.
Step 5
Hang up the handset when finished.
Note: The ability to make Multi-Site All-Call and Multi-Site Emer-
gency-All-Call pages is determined by the Class of Service (CoS) 
configuration assigned by your system administrator for your 
Admin Phone.

qas.question: What types of pages can be initiated using the Nyquist phone's display?

answers.text: The Nyquist phone's display allows users to initiate Multi-Site All-Call and Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call pages. The Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page has the highest priority and is used for emergencies, playing simultaneously across multiple configured sites.

qas.question: What is the highest priority page type mentioned in the context?

answers.text: The highest priority page type mentioned is the Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page. It is designed to play simultaneously throughout multiple configured sites and takes precedence over all other page types.

qas.question: How do you make a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page using the phone’s touchscreen?

answers.text: To make a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page using the phone's touchscreen, touch the Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call button, then talk into the phone's microphone. Finally, touch End Call when you're finished.

qas.question: What is the first step when making a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page using the handset?

answers.text: The first step when making a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page using the handset is to pick up the handset. This action will bring up the dial screen.

qas.question: What should you do after finishing a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page when using the handset?

answers.text: After finishing a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page using the handset, you should hang up the handset. This concludes the call.

qas.question: How is the ability to make Multi-Site pages determined for an Admin Phone?

answers.text: The ability to make Multi-Site All-Call and Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call pages for an Admin Phone is determined by the Class of Service (CoS) configuration assigned by the system administrator. This configuration dictates the features and permissions available for the phone.

qas.question: What is required before you can start talking during a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page on the phone's display?

answers.text: Before you can start talking during a Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call page on the phone's display, you need to touch the Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call button. Once pressed, you can then talk into the phone's microphone.

qas.question: What is a Multi-Site All-Call page, and how does it function across multiple sites?

answers.text: A Multi-Site All-Call page is a non-emergency announcement that plays simultaneously across multiple locations. It functions by allowing users to initiate the page using a touch display or handset, enabling communication throughout all intended sites seamlessly.

qas.question: How do you initiate a hands-free Multi-Site All-Call page using the touch display?

answers.text: To initiate a hands-free Multi-Site All-Call page using the touch display, touch the Multi-Site All-Call button, then talk into the phone’s microphone. Finally, touch End Call when you are finished.

qas.question: What steps are involved in making a Multi-Site All-Call page using the handset?

answers.text: To make a Multi-Site All-Call page using the handset, pick up the handset, touch the +More button on the dial screen, then select the Multi-Site All-Call button, and talk into the handset. Finally, hang up the handset when finished.

qas.question: How does an Emergency-All-Call page differ from a Multi-Site All-Call page?

answers.text: An Emergency-All-Call page is a high-priority page that simultaneously plays throughout the facility, indicating an urgent situation. In contrast, a Multi-Site All-Call page is a non-emergency page that plays simultaneously across multiple sites but does not convey the same level of urgency.

qas.question: What steps must be followed to execute a hands-free Emergency-All-Call page on the touch display?

answers.text: To execute a hands-free Emergency-All-Call page on the touch display, touch the Emergency-All-Call button, talk into the phone’s microphone, and then touch End Call when finished.

qas.question: How do you make an Emergency-All-Call page using the handset?

answers.text: To make an Emergency-All-Call page using the handset, pick up the handset and touch the +More button when the dial screen appears. Then, select the Emergency-All-Call button, talk into the handset, and hang up when finished.

qas.question: What is the main purpose of an All-Call page in comparison to Emergency-All-Call paging?

answers.text: The main purpose of an All-Call page is to communicate non-emergency information that simultaneously plays throughout the facility, while an Emergency-All-Call page is a high priority alert meant for urgent situations, also playing simultaneously but with greater urgency and importance.

qas.question: How do you initiate a hands-free All-Call page using the touch display?

answers.text: To initiate a hands-free All-Call page using the touch display, touch the All-Call button, then talk into the phone’s microphone. After you are finished speaking, touch End Call.

qas.question: What are the steps to make an All-Call page using the handset?

answers.text: To make an All-Call page using the handset, first pick up the handset and touch the +More button when the dial screen appears. Then, touch the All-Call button, talk into the handset, and hang up when finished.

qas.question: What should you do after finishing a hands-free or handset call to end the paging?

answers.text: After finishing a hands-free call, touch the "End Call" button to end the paging. If using the handset, simply hang up the handset to complete the call.

context:
Zone Paging
You can choose to page only certain areas of the facility, called zones. 
The zones, which are collections of stations, must be created through 
the Web-based System Admin User Interface (UI) before zone paging 
from the Admin Phone can occur. Zones appear in the phone’s Direc-
tory under the Paging menu. The Paging menu also includes entries 
for Facility paging.
To make a zone page using the display:
Step 1
Touch the +More button.
Step 1
Select the zone that you want to page.
Step 2
Talk into the phone’s microphone.

Step 3
Touch End Call when finished.
To make a zone page using the handset:
Step 1
Pick up the handset.
Step 2
When the dial screen appears, touch the +More but-
ton.
Step 1
Select the zone that you want to page.
Step 2
Talk into the phone’s microphone.
Step 3
Hang up the handset when finished.
3.6
Record Page
You can record a page to be added to a zone queue. The maximum 
length time for a recorded page is 60 minutes; if the recording 
exceeds 60 minutes, it will time out and not be saved. If the recording 
is silent for 60 seconds, it will time out and not be saved.
Pages in a zone’s queue are played in the order that they are placed 
in the queue. A live page started on a zone that is playing a recorded 
page will cause the recorded page to be terminated and sent back to 
the queue. The interrupted message will play again from the begin-
ning of the message when the zone becomes idle. Multi-Site Emer-
gency-All-Call, Multi-Site All-Call, Emergency All-Call, All-Call, Alarm, 
Tone, and Emergency Announcement will also interrupt any queued 
messages playing in any zones. All re-queued messages will play 
again from the beginning of the message when the applicable zones 
become idle.
Selecting Disable Audio will cause playback paging of all recorded 
messages to stop. The messages will resume play from the beginning 
when audio is re-enabled.
Note: When the DTMF Code #{Zone Number} is used to initiate a 
zone page, Nyquist will start recording a queued page if the zone 
belongs to a queue. If you want to start a real-time page to the 
zone instead, dial #{Zone Number}*.

qas.question: How are zones created for zone paging in the facility?

answers.text: Zones for zone paging in the facility must be created through the Web-based System Admin User Interface (UI) before they can be accessed for paging. Once created, zones will appear in the phone's Directory under the Paging menu.

qas.question: What are the steps to make a zone page using the display?

answers.text: To make a zone page using the display, touch the +More button, select the desired zone, speak into the phone’s microphone, and then touch End Call when finished.

qas.question: What maximum length is allowed for a recorded page in the zone queue?

answers.text: The maximum length allowed for a recorded page in the zone queue is 60 minutes. If the recording exceeds this length or is silent for 60 seconds, it will time out and not be saved.

qas.question: What happens if a recording exceeds 60 minutes or is silent for 60 seconds?

answers.text: If a recording exceeds 60 minutes or is silent for 60 seconds, it will time out and not be saved. This means that any interrupted or incomplete recordings will be discarded and will not be added to the zone queue.

qas.question: How does a live page interact with a recorded page in a zone?

answers.text: A live page started in a zone that is currently playing a recorded page will terminate the recorded page and send it back to the queue. The interrupted recorded message will play again from the beginning once the zone becomes idle.

qas.question: What types of calls can interrupt queued messages in zones?

answers.text: Queued messages in zones can be interrupted by a live page initiated on that zone, as well as by Multi-Site Emergency-All-Call, Multi-Site All-Call, Emergency All-Call, All-Call, Alarm, Tone, and Emergency Announcement. When interrupted, the queued message will replay from the beginning once the zone becomes idle.

qas.question: What is the result of selecting Disable Audio during message playback?

answers.text: Selecting Disable Audio during message playback will stop the playback of all recorded messages. The messages will resume from the beginning when audio is re-enabled.

qas.question: How can one initiate a real-time page to a zone instead of starting a queued recording?

answers.text: To initiate a real-time page to a zone instead of starting a queued recording, dial the DTMF Code #{Zone Number}* on the phone. This will bypass the queue and start a live page directly to the selected zone.

context:
11
To record a page for page queuing:
Step 1
Do one of the following:
a
Touch the Record Page button.
b
Select the soft key labeled Directory, use the navi-
gation keys to select Paging, use the navigation 
keys to select Record Page, and then press OK.
Step 2
When prompted, enter the queue number for the 
queue that you want to page and press #.
Step 3
Wait for the tone and then record your message.
Step 4
Hang up when finished.
4
Making Calls
The steps for making calls depend on whether you are making the 
call from the display and speaker or from the handset and whether 
you know the extension that you want to call.
To make a call by dialing the extension number:
Step 1
Do one of the following:
•
On the phone’s touch display, select Directory and 
then select Keypad.
•
Dial the extension number. When you start to dial, 
the keypad automatically appears.
•
Pick up the handset.
Step 2
Dial the extension. 
If using the handset, you can dial from either the touch 
display or dial pad.
Step 3
Select Send.
Step 4
When the call is completed, either hand up the handset 
or select End Call.
To make a call using the Remote Phone Book:
Step 1
Do one of the following:
•
On the phone’s display, select Directory.
•
Pick up the handset, and then select Directory.

Step 2
Ensure Remote Phone Book is selected, and then 
select Stations.
Step 3
Use the scroll bar to navigate to the station that you 
want to call, and then select that station.
Step 4
Select Send.
Step 5
When finished with the call, either select End Call or 
hang up the handset.
5
Changing the Event Schedule
Nyquist allows the setting of bells and announcements to be played 
at specific times and in specific zones. More than one schedule can 
be created for a school. For example, a school may have an early 
release day on Wednesday and have classes begin and end at differ-
ent times on that day than on the other days of the week. Based on 
this example, a Regular Schedule or an Early Release Schedule can be 
selected for the current day. 
The Schedules feature available via the Admin Phone provides a 
quick way to change the bell schedule for the day. For example, if you 
normally use an Early Release Schedule for Wednesdays but want to 
use this schedule for today (which is slated to use the Regular Sched-
ule), you can select the Early Release Schedule through the Admin 
Phone. 
To change today’s schedule:
Step 1
Touch Schedules.
Step 2
Select the schedule that you want for the day. If you 
have more than one school appearing in the Schedules 
Note: If you want to use the handset, pick up the handset and then 
select the 
 button before following the steps.

view, ensure you have selected the correct schedule for 
the correct school.
Step 3
Touch Change Schedule.

qas.question: What are the initial steps to record a page for page queuing?

answers.text: To record a page for page queuing, either touch the Record Page button or select Directory, navigate to Paging, choose Record Page, and press OK. Then, enter the desired queue number and press # to proceed.

qas.question: How do you make a call by dialing the extension number?

answers.text: To make a call by dialing the extension number, either select Directory and then Keypad on the phone’s touch display or directly dial the extension number. If using the handset, pick it up and dial the extension, then select Send to initiate the call.

qas.question: What should you do to make a call using the Remote Phone Book?

answers.text: To make a call using the Remote Phone Book, select "Directory" on the phone’s display or pick up the handset and then select "Directory." Ensure "Remote Phone Book" is selected, navigate to the desired station using the scroll bar, and then select "Send" to initiate the call.

qas.question: How can you change the event schedule using the Admin Phone?

answers.text: To change the event schedule using the Admin Phone, touch "Schedules," select the desired schedule for the day, and then touch "Change Schedule." Ensure that the correct school is selected if multiple schools are displayed.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the Schedules feature in the Nyquist system?

answers.text: The Schedules feature in the Nyquist system allows users to set bell schedules and announcements for specific times and zones within a school. This enables flexibility in adapting schedules, such as switching between regular and early release days, ensuring timely announcements and adjustments as needed.

qas.question: How do you select the correct schedule for a specific school?

answers.text: To select the correct schedule for a specific school, touch Schedules and ensure you have selected the appropriate schedule for the correct school, especially if multiple schools are appearing in the view. After confirming the correct school, touch Change Schedule to apply your selection.

qas.question: What action is required after dialing an extension number using the handset?

answers.text: After dialing an extension number using the handset, you need to select "Send" to initiate the call. Once the call is completed, either hang up the handset or select "End Call."

qas.question: What happens when you select the Record Page function?

answers.text: Selecting the Record Page function allows you to enter a queue number to page, after which you wait for a tone to record your message. Once finished, you simply hang up to complete the process.

context:
Playing Alarms
You can play a facility alarm from a list of default alarms and those 
created through the Admin Web UI.
To play an alarm:
Step 1
Do one of the following:
•
On the phone’s touch display, select Directory.
•
Pick up the handset, and then select Directory.
Step 2
Ensure Remote Phone Book is selected, and then 
select Alarms.
Step 3
Use the scroll bar to navigate to the alarm that you 
want, and then select that alarm. 
The alarm plays continuously until you manually stop it.
Step 4
To end the alarm, touch End Call or hang up the hand-
set.
Note that if you want to end an alarm that another 
Admin Phone started, select Stop Alarm.
Note: An * appears before the current schedule. 
Selecting None disables the schedule, which also disables sched-
uled tones, audio, and routines included in the schedule.

qas.question: How can you access the alarm directory on the phone?

answers.text: To access the alarm directory on the phone, either select "Directory" from the touch display or pick up the handset and then select "Directory." Ensure that "Remote Phone Book" is selected, and then choose "Alarms" to view the available alarms.

qas.question: What should you ensure is selected before choosing an alarm?

answers.text: Before choosing an alarm, ensure that "Remote Phone Book" is selected in the directory. Then, proceed to select "Alarms" to access the list of available alarms.

qas.question: How do you navigate to the desired alarm in the list?

answers.text: To navigate to the desired alarm in the list, select "Remote Phone Book" and then choose "Alarms." Use the scroll bar to scroll through the alarms until you find the one you want to play.

qas.question: What happens when you select an alarm to play?

answers.text: When you select an alarm to play, it begins to sound continuously until you manually stop it. To end the alarm, you can either touch End Call or hang up the handset. If the alarm was started by another Admin Phone, you should select Stop Alarm to end it.

qas.question: How can you manually stop an alarm once it is playing?

answers.text: To manually stop an alarm that is playing, touch "End Call" on the phone's display or hang up the handset. If the alarm was started by another Admin Phone, select "Stop Alarm."

qas.question: What should you do if you want to stop an alarm initiated by another Admin Phone?

answers.text: To stop an alarm initiated by another Admin Phone, you should select the "Stop Alarm" option instead of ending the call or hanging up the handset. This allows you to specifically terminate the alarm without affecting other functions.

qas.question: What does an asterisk (*) signify before the current schedule?

answers.text: An asterisk (*) before the current schedule signifies the active schedule. Selecting "None" will disable the schedule, along with any scheduled tones, audio, and routines associated with it.

qas.question: What happens if you select "None" in the schedule options?

answers.text: Selecting "None" in the schedule options disables the schedule, which also turns off any scheduled tones, audio, and routines included in that schedule. This means that no alarms or scheduled actions will activate.

context:
7
Playing Tones
Nyquist provides tones that can be used with events, such as bell 
schedules or announcements. In addition to the default tones, tones 
can also be created or downloaded through the Admin Web UI.
To play a tone:
Step 1
Do one of the following:
•
On the phone’s touch display, select Directory.

If your Admin Phone has the appropriate CoS parameter set, you can 
forward your calls to another Nyquist extension, whether it’s a physi-
cal station or a Web UI station. You can select to always forward calls, 
forward calls if you are on another call, or forward calls if they are not 
answered within a specified number of seconds.
The DAHDI FXS based Admin Station (also known as Analog Phone 
station Type) does not display an incoming call queue, and there is 
no incoming call queue prioritization. If the DAHDI FXS based Admin 
Station is already on a call, subsequent VoIP call-switch callers will 
continue to ring as expected. However, there is no visibility that an 
incoming call is happening, and there is no FIFO queue to handle 
multiple incoming calls.
If a VoIP phone directly calls a DAHDI FXS Admin Station that is  busy, 
the call will go to voicemail.

qas.question: How does the DAHDI FXS Admin Station respond to calls when it is already busy?

Launching Routines
You can manually launch a routine that has Allow DTMF enabled 
from an Admin Phone by doing one of the following:
• Dial *94<Routine-DTMF-Code>.
Note: The ability to manually launch routines is determined by the 
CoS configuration assigned by your system administrator for your 
Admin Phone.

• Select the Routines menu from the Admin Phone and then select 
the routine that you want to launch. 
If you disconnect the call during a routine, the routine continues until 
finished. If the routine includes Pause actions, the call will not discon-
nect until all Pause actions have been executed. 
A routine launched from the Admin Phone can end with any of the 
following page commands, provided the Admin Phone has the 
appropriate CoS enabled:
• All-Call
• Emergency-All-Call
• Facility-Page
• Mutli-Site-All-Call
• Multi-Site-Emergency-All-Call
• Zone-Page
17
Customizing Line Keys
Line keys are the soft keys that appear on the display window (see 
"Display Window Features” on page 4). Nyquist provides one key 
(located on the upper left) for user customizing, providing a “speed 
dialing” option for a feature. For example, you can customize the 
available line key to start a specific alarm. You can then select the line 
key to start the alarm rather than using the steps described in "Play-
ing Alarms” on page 13.
If you do not want to use the Nyquist defaults for line keys, you can 
reserve line keys by creating and editing a reserve line key file 
(.rlkeys), provided you are not using the Nyquist System Controller. 
Note: Only routines with Allow DTMF enabled appear in the 
menu.
Note: Depending on the CoS settings for your Admin Phone, some 
of the line keys may appear blank. For example, if your Admin 
Phone does not have Execute Routines enabled through the CoS, 
then the fourth key on the left, which by default is reserved by 
Nyquist for Routines, has a blank label.

context:
23
To create and configure a .rlkeys file:
Step 1
Identify the MAC address of your Admin Phone.
Step 2
On the Nyquist server, use the Linux command line to 
create a file in /srv/tftp called <mac-address>.rlkeys 
where <mac-address> is replaced by the Admin 
Phone’s MAC address.
Step 3
In the file created, add comma separated entries for 
each line key using the format l<line-key-number>.
For example, to reserve line keys 3, 5, and 6, you would 
type l3,l5,l6.
Step 4
Save the file.
Step 5
At the Linux command prompt, type:
chgrp www-data /srv/tftp/<mac-address>.rlkeys
chmod 664 /srv/tftp/<mac-address>.rlkeys
Step 6
At the Admin Web UI, select Stations.
Step 7
Select the Edit icon next to the station listing for your 
Admin Phone.
Step 8
Select Save.
Note: The <mac-address>.rlkeys configuration files will be saved 
in system backups. You may want to perform a system backup after 
making changes to these files, so that your changes are preserved 
whenever you perform a system restore.

qas.question: What is the first step to create a .rlkeys file for an Admin Phone?

answers.text: The first step to create a .rlkeys file for an Admin Phone is to identify the MAC address of the Admin Phone. This MAC address will be used to name the configuration file created on the Nyquist server.

qas.question: Where should the .rlkeys file be created on the Nyquist server?

answers.text: The .rlkeys file should be created in the /srv/tftp directory on the Nyquist server, with the filename corresponding to the MAC address of the Admin Phone (e.g., <mac-address>.rlkeys).

qas.question: In what format should the line keys be entered in the .rlkeys file?

answers.text: Line keys should be entered in the .rlkeys file as comma-separated entries using the format l<line-key-number>. For example, to reserve line keys 3, 5, and 6, you would type l3,l5,l6.

qas.question: What command is used to change the group ownership of the .rlkeys file?

answers.text: The command used to change the group ownership of the .rlkeys file is `chgrp www-data /srv/tftp/<mac-address>.rlkeys`. This command sets the group of the specified file to `www-data`.

qas.question: What file permissions are set for the .rlkeys file in the instructions?

answers.text: The permissions set for the .rlkeys file are 664, which allows the owner to read and write the file, the group to read and write the file, and others to read the file. This is accomplished using the `chmod 664` command in Step 5 of the instructions.

qas.question: Where do you find the option to edit the station listing for your Admin Phone?

answers.text: You can find the option to edit the station listing for your Admin Phone in the Admin Web UI under the "Stations" section. Select the Edit icon next to the listing for your specific Admin Phone to make changes.

qas.question: What should be done after editing the station listing in the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: After editing the station listing in the Admin Web UI, you should select the "Save" option to apply the changes. It's also recommended to perform a system backup to preserve the modifications made to the <mac-address>.rlkeys configuration files.

qas.question: Why is it suggested to perform a system backup after changes to .rlkeys files?

answers.text: It is suggested to perform a system backup after changes to .rlkeys files to ensure that these configurations are preserved. If a system restore is needed later, the changes made to the .rlkeys files will be retained, preventing any loss of custom settings for the Admin Phone.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the l9 key in the Nyquist server?

answers.text: The l9 key on the Nyquist server is used for Announcements and supports DTMF Code for recording announcements (*990) and stopping announcements (*93). Users can reserve this key for custom use, but will need to rely on DTMF codes for functions that are no longer accessible via the line key.

qas.question: Which DTMF code is used to record an announcement?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to record an announcement is *990. To stop the announcement, the DTMF code is *93.

qas.question: What function does the l4 key serve on the Nyquist server?

answers.text: The l4 key on the Nyquist server is normally used for Routines, and it is associated with the DTMF Code *94 followed by the specific Routine-DTMF Code. If reserved for custom use, users will need to utilize DTMF codes for accessing routines.

qas.question: How does one initiate a Multi-Site All-Call using DTMF codes?

answers.text: To initiate a Multi-Site All-Call, use the DTMF code ##0. This code is designated for the l5 key, which is reserved for Multi-Site All-Call functionality.

qas.question: What function is associated with the l10 line key?

answers.text: The l10 line key is associated with Audio Distribution, which requires using the DTMF code 987 followed by the program distribution ID. Additionally, the note mentions that some functions, including those associated with line keys like l10, do not have user-friendly DTMF alternatives.

qas.question: Is there a user-friendly DTMF code available for schedules (l11)?

answers.text: No, there is no user-friendly DTMF code available for schedules (l11). The note indicates that some functions, like those associated with line keys l10 and l11, do not have easily replaceable DTMF codes.

qas.question: What happens if you reserve a line key for personal use?

answers.text: If you reserve a line key for personal use, you will lose access to the original functions associated with that key, and you'll need to use DTMF codes to perform those functions instead. Some functions, especially those tied to line keys l10 and l11, may not have easily replaceable DTMF codes.

qas.question: What DTMF code is used to stop an announcement on the l9 key?

answers.text: The DTMF code used to stop an announcement on the l9 key is *93.

qas.question: Can you provide the DTMF code for making an Emergency All-Call with the l8 key?

answers.text: The DTMF code for making an Emergency All-Call with the l8 key is #0911.

qas.question: How can routine functions be accessed after reserving the l4 key?

answers.text: After reserving the l4 key for custom use, routine functions can still be accessed using their respective DTMF codes, which follow the format *94<Routine-DTMF-Code>. Since the l4 key will no longer be available for routines, users will need to use these DTMF codes for routine access.

qas.question: What is the DTMF code to start an alarm signal?

answers.text: The DTMF code to start an alarm signal is *91{DTMF-Code}, where {DTMF-Code} specifies the particular alarm to be activated.

qas.question: How can you call an extension using the intercom feature?

answers.text: To call an extension using the intercom feature, dial <extension> to initiate a speaker call (intercom with auto-answer). For ringing the extension instead, use *<extension>.

qas.question: What code is used to activate all-calls call forwarding?

answers.text: To activate all-calls call forwarding, the code used is **971{extension}**, where {extension} is the target extension to which calls will be forwarded.

qas.question: How do you cancel call forwarding?

answers.text: To cancel call forwarding, dial **975**. This action will disable all call forwarding settings previously configured.

qas.question: What is the DTMF code for placing a local seven-digit call?

answers.text: The DTMF code for placing a local seven-digit call is 98NNNNNNN, where NNNNNNN represents the seven-digit phone number.

qas.question: What action is performed with the DTMF code #72?

answers.text: The DTMF code #72 is used to park a call during an ongoing conversation. To retrieve a parked call, you need to dial the specific parked call’s extension number that was provided at the time of parking.

qas.question: What is the procedure for joining a conversation at an extension?

answers.text: To join a conversation at an extension, dial *#<extension>, where <extension> is the number of the station you wish to join. This procedure is authorized under the Call Any Station (CoS) rules.

qas.question: Which DTMF code is used for a blind transfer during a call?

answers.text: The DTMF code used for a blind transfer during a call is `#1<extension number>`. This code initiates the transfer to the specified extension without further interaction.

qas.question: How can you check the status of call forwarding for all users?

answers.text: To check the status of call forwarding for all users, dial **977**. This code provides the call forwarding status applicable to all users in the system.

qas.question: What emergency DTMF code can be used to call 911?

answers.text: The emergency DTMF codes to call 911 are "98911" and "911." Both codes can be used to place a 911 emergency call.

qas.question: What DTMF signal is used to initiate an attended transfer during a call?

answers.text: The DTMF signal used to initiate an attended transfer during a call is *1 followed by the extension number. This allows the caller to connect to the specified extension while still active on the initial call.

qas.question: Which DTMF command completes an attended transfer and drops out of the call?

answers.text: The DTMF command that completes an attended transfer and drops out of the call is *2.

qas.question: How can a user enable "spy mode" during call monitoring?

answers.text: A user can enable "spy mode" during call monitoring by pressing DTMF key 4. This feature allows the user to listen in on the call without being heard by the parties on the call.

qas.question: What happens if the conference owner enters 0000 as the password?

answers.text: If the conference owner enters 0000 as the password, the conference will be deleted. If an Admin station user enters 0000 but is not the conference owner, they will be prompted for the system password and the correct entry will also result in the conference's deletion.

qas.question: Which DTMF command allows a user to create or enter a dynamic conference?

answers.text: The DTMF command to create or enter a dynamic conference is **{number}**, where {number} represents the conference number. This command is accessible to users with Conference Admin or Conference User permissions.

qas.question: What is the DTMF signal for enabling "whisper mode" during call monitoring?

answers.text: The DTMF signal for enabling "whisper mode" during call monitoring is DTMF: 5. This mode allows the user to speak to the monitored party without them hearing the monitoring agent's conversation.

qas.question: How can a conference be deleted by a non-owner admin station user?

answers.text: A non-owner admin station user can delete a conference by entering the conference password "0000." If prompted, the user must then enter the correct system password to delete the conference.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the DTMF signal *4 during an attended transfer?

answers.text: The DTMF signal *4 is used to swap to the other party during an attended transfer, allowing the user to switch between the original caller and the party being transferred. This functionality helps in managing the communication flow during the transfer process.

qas.question: What is required to monitor a call or location at a specific extension?

answers.text: To monitor a call or location at a specific extension, the user must enter the command "978{extension}" while having the necessary Class of Service (CoS) for Monitoring Calls/Locations. Additionally, features like spy mode, whisper mode, or barge mode can be enabled during the monitoring session.

qas.question: Which DTMF command is used to transfer a call from a Speaker to an associated Phone?

answers.text: The DTMF command used to transfer a call from a Speaker to an associated Phone is *3. This command allows the transfer to occur while dropping the call from the Speaker.

qas.question: What is the DTMF code to start or stop recording during a call?

answers.text: The DTMF code to start or stop recording during a call is *3.

qas.question: How can users playback recorded calls?

answers.text: Users can playback recorded calls by dialing 999, which is designated for managing recordings. This allows them to access and listen to previously recorded calls.

qas.question: What DTMF code is used for an emergency all-call page?

answers.text: The DTMF code for an emergency all-call page is 951. Additionally, #0911 can also be used for an emergency all-call page.

qas.question: How can announcements be recorded using the admin phone?

answers.text: Announcements can be recorded using the admin phone by dialing *990 or by selecting "Record Announcement" from the Announce menu. After recording, the announcement will be assigned a DTMF code corresponding to its row ID, which can be changed later via the web interface.

qas.question: What does the saved announcement's default "Play to Zone" setting indicate?

answers.text: The saved announcement's default "Play to Zone" setting is set to blank, indicating that no specific zone is selected for playback. This means that when the announcement is played via an IP phone, the user must enter a zone number, where 0 signifies playing to all speakers.

qas.question: How can the DTMF code for a recorded announcement be changed after saving?

answers.text: The DTMF code for a recorded announcement can be changed after saving by editing the announcement in the web interface Announcements view. After recording the announcement using *990 or through the Admin phone's Announce menu, you can update the DTMF code associated with the saved announcement's row ID.

qas.question: What is the function of the #0 code in the paging system?

answers.text: The #0 code in the paging system is used for All-Call Paging, allowing messages to be broadcasted to all speakers simultaneously. It falls under the Class of Service (CoS) for All-Call Paging.

qas.question: What does "CoS" stand for in the context of paging and announcements?

answers.text: "CoS" stands for "Class of Service" in the context of paging and announcements. It refers to the different categories that determine the access and functionalities available for various features such as emergency calls, all-call paging, and recording announcements. Each CoS is associated with specific permissions and capabilities within the system.

qas.question: How can users define a permanent zone number for a saved announcement?

answers.text: Users can define a permanent zone number for a saved announcement by updating the "Play to Zone" setting after the recorded announcement has been saved in the web interface Announcements view. By specifying a zone number, they can designate where the announcement will be played, with 0 indicating all speakers.

qas.question: What is the distinction between multi-site and standard all-call paging?

answers.text: Multi-site all-call paging allows for announcements to be broadcast simultaneously across multiple sites or locations, facilitating communication over a broader geographic area. In contrast, standard all-call paging is limited to a single site or location, targeting only the speakers within that specific area.

qas.question: What is the purpose of the code ##{Facility Number}?

answers.text: The code ##{Facility Number} is used to initiate an all-call page to a specified facility number. It falls under the Class of Service (CoS) category of Inter-Facility Call/Page, allowing for broadcast communication within the facility.

qas.question: How can a user page a specific zone at a facility?

answers.text: A user can page a specific zone at a facility by dialing ##{Facility Number}#{Zone Number} to send a zone page or by dialing ##{Facility Number}#{Zone Number}* for a real-time page to that zone.

qas.question: What does the DTMF code *92{DTMF-Code} do?

answers.text: The DTMF code *92{DTMF-Code} initiates a specific announcement as specified by the {number} provided in place of {DTMF-Code}. This function is categorized under the Class of Service (CoS): All-Call Page.

qas.question: How is a recorded page initiated and what is the prompt provided by the system?

answers.text: A recorded page is initiated by dialing *991, after which the system will prompt for the Zone Number. For a specific zone, the code *991*{Zone Number} can be used to directly record a page for that zone.

qas.question: What does the code *992 do in the context of Zone Paging?

answers.text: In the context of Zone Paging, the code *992 cancels a recorded page for the specified zone. This functionality allows users to stop the announcement that was previously recorded in that particular zone.

qas.question: How can someone access their own voicemail using a DTMF code?

answers.text: To access their own voicemail, a person can dial the DTMF code 900. This code directly connects them to their voicemail for the current caller.

qas.question: What is the format for leaving a voicemail for a specified extension?

answers.text: To leave a voicemail for a specified extension, use the format **904{extension}***, where {extension} is the number of the intended recipient's extension.

qas.question: How does the Walking Class of Service feature work with an authorization code?

answers.text: The Walking Class of Service feature allows a user to change the current IP phone's extension to a specified {extension} by entering the authorization code followed by the desired extension. This action is initiated using the DTMF code sequence 3*{authCode}*{extension}. However, if the authorization code is set to 0000 in the Admin Web UI, this feature is disabled.

qas.question: What happens if the authorization code is set to 0000 in the Admin Web UI?

answers.text: If the authorization code is set to 0000 in the Admin Web UI's System Parameters, the Walking Class of Service feature is disabled, meaning that users cannot change their current IP phone's extension using this code.

qas.question: Which DTMF codes require the user to be at the same extension that created the recorded page?

answers.text: The DTMF codes that require the user to be at the same extension that created the recorded page are *991*{Zone Number} for recording the page and *992*{Zone Number} for canceling the recorded page. These codes only function if used from the same extension as the one that initiated the recorded page.

qas.question: What is the dial code for a normal call to the admin station?

answers.text: The dial code for a normal call to the admin station is **0**. This code initiates the check-in process for a station when dialed.

qas.question: How do you initiate an emergency call to the admin?

answers.text: To initiate an emergency call to the admin, dial *0 from your station. This will establish an emergency connection to the admin station.

qas.question: Which dial code is used to start audio distribution for a specific DTMF code?

answers.text: The dial code used to start audio distribution for a specific DTMF code is 987*{DTMF-Code}. This allows the initiation of audio distribution associated with the specified DTMF code.

qas.question: What command stops all scheduled audio?

answers.text: The command to stop all scheduled audio is 920. This code can be used to halt any audio that has been scheduled for playback.

qas.question: How can a routine be executed using a DTMF code?

answers.text: A routine can be executed using a DTMF code by dialing *94 followed by the specific <Routine-DTMF-Code>. Alternatively, you can also use 0000094 followed by the <Routine-DTMF-Code> to execute the routine.

qas.question: What is the function of the toggle audio distribution command?

answers.text: The toggle audio distribution command (*9) is used to switch the audio distribution on or off for the associated speaker. This allows real-time control over audio output to the designated speaker within the system.

qas.question: Which dial code disables audio in the system?

answers.text: The dial code to disable audio in the system is 0000097. This code is part of the Control of Services (CoS) for disabling audio.

qas.question: What do you dial to open a contact number on an I/O Controller?

answers.text: To open a contact number on an I/O Controller, you dial 943#{extension}#{contact-number}. For example, dialing 943#120#1 opens contact number 1 on I/O Controller 120.

qas.question: How do you restart the Nyquist system server?

answers.text: To restart the Nyquist system server, dial the code #*349. This code is designated specifically for that purpose.

qas.question: What sequence is used to enable audio in the system?

answers.text: To enable audio in the system, use the dial code `0000098`. This command falls under the category of "CoS: Enable Audio."
